davek725 wrote:
> My company is currently doing TDD and using JUnit for our unit
> testing - both persistence testing and business logic testing.  We
> are now looking at Agitator and trying to determine if, and how, it
> fits into our current practices.  I was wondering how others have
> decided to use Agitator (or not use it).  Some of the issues we are
> struggling with:
> 
> 1.  Agitator looks like it can eliminate the need to write most JUnit
> tests (except true persistence testing).  The downside is that we
> would be left with only Agitator config files that contain our
> business logic assertions.  This seems like a big leap to take, given
> that if Agitar goes away, we have no JUnit.
> 
> 2.  Agitator mocks and factories look easy to create, but look like
> they are only useful in the context of Agitator.  I couldn't use them
> for other purposes (e.g. Fitnesse, JUnit).
> 
> 3.  Having my business logic tests in JUnit means they are in an
> understood format and things such as inputs and expected results are
> clearly visible and grouped with each test.  My impression of
> Agitator is that this wouldn't be as clear.

I find the notion that Agitator outcomes replace JUnit tests to be at 
best questionable and at worst troubling. It's steeped in the notion 
that TDD is about testing, and it isn't.

If your team wants to practice TDD, then it can use Agitator to 
supplement help find tests you missed when you were test-driving your 
code. As you get better at TDD, you rely on Agitator less, but there 
will always be some gap between the tests you need to test-drive your 
design and the tests you need to cover your codebase adequately (say, 
85%). For top TDD practitioners, that gap is very small, but for people 
still learning to write JUnit tests and do TDD, the gap is larger. In 
this case, Agitator helps quite a bit.

Also, Agitator can help retrofit tests to legacy code, however it 
/doesn't/ help you identify the specific design problems in that code, 
nor does it motivate you to improve the design. This might or might not 
concern your team at this time.

On my next real Java project, I will probably want to use Agitator to 
help me find tests I missed, but not to replace writing any particular 
JUnit tests. Without those tests, I don't design well.

Take care.
